Opposition leaders called for a "March of One Million", from the Arabic {{lang|ar|ÙØ³ÙØ±Ø© ÙÙÙÙÙÙØ©}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/1BCBED22-E192-4A34-BED1-1C7146436175.htm |title=Ø¨Ø¯Ø¡ Ø§ÙØªØ¬ÙØ¹ ÙÙÙØ¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø© Ø§ÙÙÙÙÙÙÙØ©|publisher=Aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-03-06}}</ref> ''masÄ«rat milyÅna'')<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/01/31/world/main7301297.shtml |title=Egypt Opposition Plans "March of Millions" |publisher=CBS News |date=2011-01-31 |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tagesschau.de/multimedia/bilder/kairo206.html |title=Marsch der Millionen: In Kairo marschieren die Massen gegen Mubarak|work=[[Tagesschau (Germany)|Tagesschau]]|trans_title=|language=[[German language|German]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> from Cairo's Tahrir Square to the [[Heliopolis Palace|Presidential Palace]] in [[Heliopolis (Cairo suburb)|Heliopolis]] on 1 February.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/01/31/3126194.htm|title=Egypt Protesters Call for Million-Man March|publisher=Abc.net.au|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title='Mega Protest' Planned in Egypt|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=31 January 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/20111316148317175.html|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> Egyptian security forces fortified Mubarak's presidential palace with coils of [[barbed wire]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/opinion/2011/0202/1224288768049.html|title=West Has Little To Fear from Arab Populism|author=Staunton, Denis|date=2 February 2011|work=[[The Irish Times]] |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
Opposition leaders called for a "March of One Million", from the Arabic {{lang|ar|ÙØ³ÙØ±Ø© ÙÙÙÙÙÙØ©}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/1BCBED22-E192-4A34-BED1-1C7146436175.htm |title=Ø¨Ø¯Ø¡ Ø§ÙØªØ¬ÙØ¹ ÙÙÙØ¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø© Ø§ÙÙÙÙÙÙÙØ©|publisher=Aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-03-06}}</ref> ''masÄ«rat milyÅna'')<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/01/31/world/main7301297.shtml |title=Egypt Opposition Plans "March of Millions" |publisher=CBS News |date=2011-01-31 |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tagesschau.de/multimedia/bilder/kairo206.html |title=Marsch der Millionen: In Kairo marschieren die Massen gegen Mubarak|work=[[Tagesschau (Germany)|Tagesschau]]|trans_title=|language=[[German language|German]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> from Cairo's Tahrir Square to the [[Heliopolis Palace|Presidential Palace]] in [[Heliopolis (Cairo suburb)|Heliopolis]] on 1 February.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/01/31/3126194.htm|title=Egypt Protesters Call for Million-Man March|publisher=Abc.net.au|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title='Mega Protest' Planned in Egypt|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=31 January 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/20111316148317175.html|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> Egyptian security forces fortified Mubarak's presidential palace with coils of [[barbed wire]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/opinion/2011/0202/1224288768049.html|title=West Has Little To Fear from Arab Populism|author=Staunton, Denis|date=2 February 2011|work=[[The Irish Times]] |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
Line 127: Line 128:
The United Nations human rights chief [[Navi Pillay]] announced that there were reports that more than 300 people had died in the violence with up to 3,000 injured, although stressed that these reports remain unconfirmed.<ref name="300 Killed">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/300-killed-so-far-in-Egypt-protests-20110201|title='300 Killed' So Far in Egypt Protests|publisher=[[South African Press Association]] (via ''[[News24]]'')|date=18 December 2010|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Meanwhile banks closed, making it difficult for people to get cash to buy food; for those that have money and prices skyrocketed as consumers flood the few open stores.<ref>{{cite web|last=Galal |first=Ola |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-01/egyptians-face-soaring-food-prices-by-day-looters-at-night-amid-turmoil.html |title=Egyptians Face Food Inflation by Day, Looters by Night |work=[[Bloomberg]] |date= |accessdate=1 February 2011}}{{dead link|date=March 2011}}</ref> [[Recep Tayyip Erdogan]], Turkey's Prime Minister, urged Mubarak to meet his people's "desire for change".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/31/live-blog-feb-1-egypt-protests|title=Turkey's Prime Minister Weighs in on the Crisis|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
The United Nations human rights chief [[Navi Pillay]] announced that there were reports that more than 300 people had died in the violence with up to 3,000 injured, although stressed that these reports remain unconfirmed.<ref name="300 Killed">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/300-killed-so-far-in-Egypt-protests-20110201|title='300 Killed' So Far in Egypt Protests|publisher=[[South African Press Association]] (via ''[[News24]]'')|date=18 December 2010|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Meanwhile banks closed, making it difficult for people to get cash to buy food; for those that have money and prices skyrocketed as consumers flood the few open stores.<ref>{{cite web|last=Galal |first=Ola |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-01/egyptians-face-soaring-food-prices-by-day-looters-at-night-amid-turmoil.html |title=Egyptians Face Food Inflation by Day, Looters by Night |work=[[Bloomberg]] |date= |accessdate=1 February 2011}}{{dead link|date=March 2011}}</ref> [[Recep Tayyip Erdogan]], Turkey's Prime Minister, urged Mubarak to meet his people's "desire for change".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/31/live-blog-feb-1-egypt-protests|title=Turkey's Prime Minister Weighs in on the Crisis|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
â   â
[[File:Cairo female protesters with colorful signs - 1FEB2011.jpg|thumb|Young protesters in Cairo. The middle sign reads: "Mubarak leave us and go look for someone else to gross out other than us."<ref>{{cite web|author=By monasosh Mona+ Add Contact |url=http://www.flickr.com/photos/89031137@N00/5410500494/ |title=IMG00743-20110201-1112 | Flickr - Photo Sharing! |publisher=Flickr |date=2011-02-01 |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref>]]
 
In the late evening (11:00 PM local Egyptian time) President Mubarak proclaimed that he did not intend to run in the next election.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charter.net/video/play/429076/channels/cnn |title=Mubarak Video|publisher=Charter.net |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Mubarak said he would stay in office to ensure a peaceful transition to the next election, [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|set for September 2011]], and promised to make political reforms. He also said that he would demand that Egyptian authorities pursue "outlaws" and "investigate those who caused the security disarray." Mubarak said that peaceful protests were transformed into "unfortunate clashes, mobilised and controlled by political forces that wanted to escalate and worsen the situation". He called upon the [[Parliament of Egypt|Egyptian parliament]] to change the term limits of the presidency and to change the requirements to run for president. He also accepted the legal charges against parliament members which meant a great amount of the parliament members would be changed through the legal process.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE7102JP20110201?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true |title=Text â President Mubarak's Speech after Mass Protest |work=[[Reuters]] |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
In the late evening (11:00 PM local Egyptian time) President Mubarak proclaimed that he did not intend to run in the next election.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charter.net/video/play/429076/channels/cnn |title=Mubarak Video|publisher=Charter.net |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Mubarak said he would stay in office to ensure a peaceful transition to the next election, [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|set for September 2011]], and promised to make political reforms. He also said that he would demand that Egyptian authorities pursue "outlaws" and "investigate those who caused the security disarray." Mubarak said that peaceful protests were transformed into "unfortunate clashes, mobilised and controlled by political forces that wanted to escalate and worsen the situation". He called upon the [[Parliament of Egypt|Egyptian parliament]] to change the term limits of the presidency and to change the requirements to run for president. He also accepted the legal charges against parliament members which meant a great amount of the parliament members would be changed through the legal process.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE7102JP20110201?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true |title=Text â President Mubarak's Speech after Mass Protest |work=[[Reuters]] |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
